results.question: Why have RSUs been omitted when calculating diluted earnings per share for 2018 and 2017?
gold_answer: RSUs have been omitted as they are out-of-the-money and thus anti-dilutive
results.markdown_table_response: On 2019, the RSUs were suspended and the RSUs are no longer needed, as they are no longer anti-dilutive. Therefore, the diluted earnings per share for 2018 and 2017 are the same.
results.csv_string_response:
Answer:
RSUs are included in the diluted earnings per share calculations for 2018 and 2017 because, as noted, they are out-of-the-money and thus anti-dilutive. This is because, as discussed in note 1, the RSUs are purchased on a forward-looking basis, as opposed to a basis on which the RSUs are invested. This means that the RSUs are out-of-the-money when compared to the amount that would have been invested in their shares. This is why the diluted earnings per share calculations for 2018 and 2017 are omitted.

results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?
gold_answer: by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.
results.markdown_table_response:
(In thousands)
Basic earnings per share, or EPS, is calculated by dividing net income (loss) per share by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income per share by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common shares outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.
For purposes of this calculation, common stock options, restricted stock units and restricted stock awards are considered to be common stock equivalents and are only included in the calculation of diluted EPS when their effect is dilutive. In periods in which the Company has a net loss, dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted EPS.
The table below presents the computation of basic and diluted earnings per share:
For the years ended December 31, 2019, 2018 and 2017, the Company incurred net losses and accordingly excluded common stock equivalents for outstanding stockbased awards, which represented all potentially dilutive securities, of 2.5 million, 3.7 million, and 4.5 million, respectively, from the calculation of diluted net loss per share due to their anti-dilutive nature.
results.json_rows_response: EPS is calculated by dividing net income (loss) per share, excluding common stock equivalents, by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income per share by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period.

results.question: What led to lower capital expenditures at Bell Media in 2019?
gold_answer: production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018
results.markdown_table_response: Bell Media reduced capital expenditures by $6 million in 2019 compared to 2018. This was primarily driven by lower capital expenditures for the wireline segment, as we deployed our LTE-A network and fixed WTTP in rural locations to enhance coverage and network speeds, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology.
results.csv_string_response: The following is a summary of the answers to the question:
results.json_rows_response:
Capital expenditures at Bell Media in 2019 were $3,988  million, down $17 million compared to 2018. This corresponded to a capital intensity ratio of 16.6% and a net capital spending increase of 0.3 pts compared to last year. The year-over-year increase in capital spending was primarily due to the following:
• Increase in capital expenditures at our wireless segment of $33 million, compared to 2018, as we continued to advance the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital expenditures at our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to 2018, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades
